title: Fatal: Error starting protocol stack: missing block number for head header hash
body:
Hi there!

I got this error right before the Geth almost full sync:
````
Fatal: Error starting protocol stack: missing block number for head header hash
````
I'm using a EC2 only for the Ethereum node, nothing else is running on this vm.
My EC2 is a t2.Xlarge with 16GB RAM and 8 Cores
My storage is 800GB EBS with 2400 IOPS


Is there a way to fix this ? or revert some of the blocks and continue with sync ?
Don't want to start syncing from the start again.

#### System information

Geth version: `1.9.3-stable`
Go : go1.12.9.linux.amd64
OS & Version: CentOS Linux

#### Expected behaviour

Geth to sincronize 

#### Actual behaviour

I get this error when almost finishing full sync:

````
Fatal: Error starting protocol stack: missing block number for head header hash
````

#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour

I ran Geth with the following parameters :

````
geth --datadir ~/NODES/ethmainnet --identity GMCNODE --rpc --rpccorsdomain "*" --rpcaddr "0.0.0.0" --rpcport "8545" --syncmode "full" --nousb  --cache=512
````

First up, why did you limit Geth to 512MB cache (default if you don't specify anything is 4GB for mainnet), if you have such a powerful machine?

Secondly, my hunch is that your system ran out of file descriptors, so leveldb failed to write something to disk. The reason seems to be that someone/thing is hammering your node via the RPC (please never open the RPC for the public internet).

There's no simple way to recover, but one thing you can do to not download all the data again is to delete all the files from your `chaindata` folder **except (!!!)** the `ancient` folder. That way only the state needs to be downloaded again. Still, please bump the cache (or not set it at all), otherwise sync is significantly slower than it could be.

Hey @karalabe thanks for the hint, I will erase the chain data folder except te ancient, and try to sync again.

As for the 512MB cache, it was the only config that did the trick, if I did not set it, or set it 1024MB or other value, I get the error 
````
runtime: out of memory: cannot allocate 3465216-byte block (3685285888 in use)
fatal error: out of memory
````

Wait, are you using a 32 bit build? Please use a 64bit binary.
